Award.AwardTitle: Neutrino Particle Astrophysics at the University of Maryland
Award.AbstractNarration:
Particle astrophysics explores some of the most tantalizing questions at the intersection of contemporary astrophysics and particle physics. These include the nature, source and acceleration mechanism of cosmic rays, neutrino properties, the search for dark matter and monopoles, and an understanding of extraordinarily energetic phenomena such as gamma ray bursts (GRBs) and active galactic nuclei. The recent first-ever observational evidence, by the IceCube Observatory, of high-energy neutrinos from distant astrophysical sources ushers in the long awaited era of neutrino astrophysics and promises to open a new window on the universe to provide information on the acceleration mechanisms at work in these sources and insight into the nature and source of cosmic radiation.

The IceCube Observatory was constructed at the U.S. Antarctic Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station and the detector deployment was completed in Dec 2010 with initial operation of the full detector commencing in Spring 2011. IceCube is comprised of 5160 photomultiplier tubes instrumenting a full cubic kilometer of ice and is the largest neutrino detector in existence. This award provides funds to support this group's contributions to the operation of this unique instrument. In addition to providing leadership within the IceCube Collaboration, the group will continue their analysis of IceCube data focusing on continuing searches for neutrino emission from GRBs, real-time neutrino searches and neutrino oscillations.

The group has an established track record in both public outreach and providing strong scientific and educational opportunities for undergraduates, graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows. They will continue their work by bringing particle astrophysics to high schools and the public through their QuarkNet chapter, as well as through science fair judging and public lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project are to broaden our basic knowledge of the physical universe through the use and measurement of neutrinos. The neutrinos are used as astrophysical messenger particles by detecting them in the South Pole IceCube neutrino detector, which measures their energy, direction and lepton flavor in order to 1) elucidate the origin of high energy cosmic rays and determine the astrophysical mechanisms at work in the highest energy objects in the universe; and 2) use the neutrinos detected in the IceCube instrument to determine fundamental properties of the neutrinos themselves, which are one of the elementary building blocks of matter and could provide a unique way to study the landscape of Grand Unified Theories and the nature of CP violation. These are fundamental to understanding the origin of the matter-antimatter asymmetry in our universe.

The research during this award had a number of very high-profile results. The highlight was the world’s first compelling evidence of an astrophysical source of both high-energy neutrinos and photons from a distant active galaxy. The result has recently been submitted to the Journal science for publication.

This represents the next milestone of the decades long goal of building a kilometer-cubed neutrino detector with sensitivity sufficient to detect distant astrophysical objects outside our galaxy with a new messenger particle, the neutrino. The observation of the high-energy neutrino in coincidence with radio, optical, x-ray and gamma-ray observations of flaring blazar consistent with the direction of the neutrino are a major step forward in the field of multi-messenger astrophysics. In the decade to come, we hope to use this new multi-messenger astrophysics to help us understand the astrophysical mechanisms at work in the highest energy objects and processes at work in our universe and will hopefully ultimately solve the 100-year-old mystery on what is the source of the highest energy cosmic rays.
